To date, based on the immunological and biological properties, three types of influenza viruses including A, B, and C have been recognized.
1, 2 Due to their fatal potential and highly contagious nature, influenza viruses have more predominant effects on communities rather than common respiratory illnesses.
3 Risk factors such as diabetes, respiratory and cardiovascular disorders are particularly making subjects (especially elderly patients) susceptible to hospitalizations and complications.
4 Influenza epidemics of variable extent and severity impose an immense burden in terms of morbidity, mortality and economic and social costs.
